questions.text: A 52 year old man with history of coronary artery disease is currently on sublingual nitroglycerin 0.5 mg, S0S, metoprolol 50 mg twice a day, aspirin 75 mg once a day, enalapril 5 ma once a day, for the last one year. The patient is now complaining of breathlessness and wheeze. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated for this new symptom?

A patient with ischaemic heart disease on regular follow-up has a resting heart rate of 90 beats/minute. The patient is taking metoprolol 50 mg twice a day. Which one of the following drugs may be added to his prescription if he also has signs of heart failure?

An 18 year old boy got frost bite of left feet after working in a snowy feld for 5-6 hours. He complained of paln, numbness and limited moment of his toes. The skin appeared white and waxy. Which one of the tollowing Is contradicted as initial treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Rewarming by immersion of feet in water bath at 40-44°C

options.label: C
options.text: Cleaning of injured area with soap

options.label: D
options.text: Use of analgesia and sterile dressing

Which of the following are Controller Therapies in the management of acute asthma? 1. Anticholinergics 2. Systemic glucocorticoids 3. Inhaled glucocorticoids 4. Omalizumab Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Alternative Therapies: Nonpharmacologic treatments, including hypnosis, acupuncture, chiropraxis, breathing control, yoga, and speleotherapy. may be popular with some patients.
  • • Bronchial Thermoplasty: Bronchial thermoplasty is a bronchoscopic treatment using thermal energy to ablate airway smooth muscle in accessible bronchi. It may reduce exacerbations in patients not controlled on maximal inhaler therapy.

Acetylcholine receptors in the pre-junctional membrane are involved 4. Penicillamine may precipitate similar illness Select the correct answer using the code given below:

Which one of the following is correct regarding blood components in clinical practice?

options.label: A
options.text: ABO blood group antigens are polypeptide chains on the surface of RBCs

options.label: B
options.text: Platelets can be stored for upto 35 days

options.label: C
options.text: Hemolytic disease of newborn occurs when mother's IgA anti RBC antibodies cross the placenta and lyse fetal RBCs

options.label: D
options.text: Transfusion associated GVHD can be prevented by prior irradiation of transfused blood

questions.correct_answer: D. Transfusion associated GVHD can be prevented by prior irradiation of transfused blood
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • ? ABO blood group antigens are oligosaccharide chains that project from the red cell surface which attached to proteins and lipids of red cell membrane
  • • ? If RhD-positive red cells enter the circulation of an RhD-negative mother, IgG antibodies are produced. It crosses placenta and cause hemolysis and severe neurological damage or death due to haemolytic disease of the newborn. For prevention RhD-negative women should be given anti-D perinatally.
  • • ? Most frequent causes of death were transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) (32%), followed by TRALI (26%), hemolysis (18%), and sepsis (14%).
  • • ? Malaria is less severe in type O than non-O patients. Blood group O is susceptible to Helicobacter pylori.
  • • ? RBC Ag may be the target of autoantibodies generating autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Some of them, mostly IgG, are active at 37°C, called "warm autoantibodies," and are most often directed against Rh Ag, while others, most often IgM, are active at 4°C, called "cold autoantibodies," and may be directed against ABO, I. I. P, and other Ag
  • • ? 43 RBC group systems described, five (Rh, Kell, Duffy, Kidd, and MNS) are routinely investigated with transfusion compatibility of 95% Platelets stored At 20-24°C and under permanent motion for 3-7 days (5 day Davidson) or At 4°C without motion: up to 14-21 days, If irradiated: <24 h
  • • Complication of transfusion:-
  • • Acute haemolytic reactions may present with hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, fever (+1-2°C), chills, chest and back pain, haemoglobinuria. and hemoglobinemia. In severe cases, DIC, acute renal failure, shock, and death may occur.
  • • Delayed hemolytic reactions present with icterus and persisting or worsening anemia. There may be elevated plasma LDH and unconjugated bilirubin. The direct antiglobulin test (direct Coombs test) that detects immunoglobulin, and possibly complement (C3d), on the surface of the recipient's RBC and indirect antiglobulin test (indirect Coombs test) that detects anti-RBC alloAb in the serum will also be positive. Management- supportive; stop transfusion, vigorous hydration with isotonic saline and diuretics to maintain urine output; may require forced alkaline diuresis, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and pressor support as needed. In case of DIC and severe bleeding - PC, plasma, and cryoprecipitate or fibrinogen may needed.
  • • Posttransfusion Purpura:-Rare and defined as a thrombocytopenia-related bleeding disorder developing 5-12 days after PC (rarely RBCC) transfusion, mainly in women. Mechanism unknown. Management - supportive but may require polyvalent immunoglobulin, steroids, or plasma exchange. Additional platelet transfusions may worsen the thrombocytopenia.
  • • Graft-versus-Host Disease - Extremely rare after transfusion, but frequent complication of allergenic hematopoietic transplantation. Transfusion- associated GVHD is highly resistant to treatment with immunosuppressive therapies as well as ablative therapy followed by allogeneic bone marrow transplantation and is fatal in >90% of cases. Prevention - Gamma or X-ray irradiation of cellular BC or treating BC with pathogen reduction. At-risk patients are: inherited immune deficiency, Hodgkin lymphoma, patients with aplastic anaemia receiving immunosuppressive therapy with antithymocyte globulin, patients undergoing autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic transplantation, those taking T-lymphocyte-suppressing drugs, such as fludarabine and other purine or pyrimidine analogues, anti-CD52 Ab or antithymocyte globulin, fetuses receiving intrauterine transfusions, and recipients of BC given by blood relative. Granulocyte concentrates contain a large number of lymphocytes, so always be irradiated.
  • • TACO:-Risk factors are older age, renal failure, preexisting fluid overload, cardiac dysfunction, administration of a large volume of BCs, and an excessive rate of transfusion comparative to hemodynamic tolerance. C/F- Dyspnea, hypoxia, bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates on chest x-ray, frequent systolic hypertension, and elevated brain natriuretic peptide, Fever may also exist. Prevention - identifying at-risk patients, close monitoring, a slow transfusion rate and use of diuretics in hemodynamically stable patients. Treatment requires stopping the transfusion and administrating oxygen and diuretics.
  • • Electrolyte imbalance- Transfusion total blood volume over 3 h or >5-10 units of RBCCs cause citrate toxicity, hypothermia and cardiac dysrhythmias, (due to BC at 4°C), hyperkalemia, and dilutional coagulopathy, Citrate chelates calcium causing hypocalcemia, manifested by circumoral paresthesia, and changes in cardiac function
  • • Iron overload. Each unit of RBCs contains 200-250 mg of iron, its accumulation affect endocrine, hepatic, and cardiac function. Acute hypotensive transfusion reactions defined as an abrupt drop in blood pressure of >30 mmHg carly after the start of transfusion and resolving quickly once the transfusion is stopped, without further intervention.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an oral direct Thrombin inhibitor?

Which of the following are correct with regard to metformin? 1. The maximum tolerated dose is 2000 mg/day 2. Lactic acidosis is the major adverse effect of metformin 3. It may lower the blood levels of Vitamin B12 level Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Some newer agents clearly protect against cardiovascular disease (GLP-1 receptor agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors), but are more expensive. Others (metformin and thiazolidinediones) provide some cardiovascular protection, but are cheaper, while others do not (sulphonylureas, DPP-4 inhibitors and insulin). SGLT2 inhibitors have additional protective properties in heart failure and diabetic kidney disease, while TZDs (thiazolidinediones) increase rates of heart failure.
  • • Approaches to drug therapy in type 2 DM:-
  • • Improve insulin availability- Exogenous insulin, Sulfonylureas, Meglitinide/phenylalanine analogues, Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP 4is), and GLP-1 receptor agonists
  • • Overcome insulin resistance- Biguanides (Metformin), Thiazolidinediones (Pioglitazone), a-glucosidase inhibitors

questions.text: A 21 year young female was brought to Emergency Department with history of unknown substance ingestion. She was having vomiting, profuse diarrhoea, bronchorrhoea and excessive sweating. On examination miosis and muscular fasciculations were present. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young female of 22 year old presented to the medical emergency with complaints of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and convulsions along with methaemoglobulinemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Causes:-Non-toxic (Congenital methaemoglobinaemias). Toxic Dapsone and topical anaesthetics such as benzocaine are the most common others are organic nitrites, nitrates, aniline derivatives, chloroquine, primaquine, chlorobenzene, naphthalene, copper sulphate, nitrogen oxides, nitro- and nitrosohydrocarbons, phenazopyridine, sulphonamides.
  • • Acquired methemoglobinemia and methemoglobinemia due to deficiency of CYB5R3 are more common than the M hemoglobins.
  • • Features are:-left shift of haemoglobin- oxygen dissociation curve, oxygen delivery to tissues is reduced, apparent cyanosis, breathlessness, fatigue, headache and chest pain, delirium, impaired consciousness and seizures. In methaemoglobinaemia - SpO2 will tend towards 85%.
  • • Treatment:- IV Methylthioninium chloride(methylene blue). Ascorbic acid is preferable in people who are glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficient
  • • Copper sulphate- Fungicide; features of toxicity are nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, discoloured (blue/green) secretions, corrosive effects on the gastrointestinal tract, renal or liver failure, methaemoglobinaemia, haemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, convulsions and coma. Symptomatic + IV methylene blue)
  • • Chemical warfare agent:- (Note- question may be asked in future)

Bone Marrow Iron Stores 2. Percent transferrin saturation 3. Serum ferritin 4. Total Iron Binding Capacity Select the correct answer using the code given below:

Which of the following drugs carry a definite risk of causing clinical haemolysis in persons suffering from Glucose-6 phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency? 1. Primaquine 2. Dapsone 3. Cotrimoxazole 4. Nitrofurantoin Select the correct answer using the code given below:

A 40 year old male presented with complaints of generalised weakness, weight loss, abdominal discomfort and decreased appetite. On examination Splenomegaly (massive) was present. On investigation it was found that haemoglobin was 7-0 g/dL, platelet count - 8 lakh per cubic mm, WBC-90000 per cubic mm. Most probably this is the case of
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) :- This is predominantly a disease of childhood with a mean age of 2-4 years. Acute lymphocytic leukemia:-
  • • ? Infiltration of bone marrow leads to anemia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia with the clinical manifestations of fatigue, weakness, infection, and hemorrhage. These symptoms are more often the reason a patient first seeks medical advice rather than consequences of tumor bulk, such as lymph node enlargement, hepatosplenomegaly caused by leukemic infiltration, or symptoms of the central nervous system (meningeosis leukemica).
  • • ? Most frequent neoplastic disease in children with an early peak at the age of 3-4 years. Philadelphia chromosome-positive (ALL BCR/ABL translocation) is observed in half of elderly B-lineage patients.
  • • ? Etiology is unknown. Exposure to ionizing radiation or to chemicals, including prior chemotherapy, is associated with an increased risk of developing leukemia, cytostatic treatment with alkylating agents and topoisomerase inhibitors. Klinefelter's syndrome, Fanconi's anemia, A Bloom's syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and neurofibromatosis, Down's syndrome has increase risk AML at an older age.
  • • ? WBC reduced or normal in 40%, in 16% above 100 x 10' / L. >75% blast cell in peripheral blood in 36% cases. Peripheral blood characteristically shows anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In one third patient Hb is <7-8 g/dL, platelet < 20 x 10'/L and neutropenia (neutrophils <0.5 x 10'/L), is associated infection. The bone marrow is heavily packed with leukemic blast cells with >90%.
  • • ? CSF examination is an essential. CNS leukemia is diagnosed if 25 cells/µL or leukemic blast cells were observed. LP is restricted to platelet count (>20 x 109/L) and without hemorrhages. To eliminate potentially transferred blast cells, patients should receive intrathecal methotrexate at the first lumbar puncture. > 70% of adult ALLs are of B-cell origin, and the most frequent immunologic subtype. Approximately 25% of adult ALL are of T-cell lineage.
  • • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • • ? Most common variety of leukaemia, accounting for 30% of cases. M: F ratio 2:1 and the median age at presentation is 65-70 years. Characterised by the clonal expansion of small mature-looking B cells; onset is usually insidious.
  • • ? May present as anaemia, infections, painless lymphadenopathy, and night sweats or weight loss
  • • ? Diagnosis is based on the peripheral blood findings of a mature lymphocytosis (>5 x 109/L) with characteristic morphology and cell surface markers. Immunophenotyping reveals the lymphocytes to be monoclonal B cells expressing the B-cell antigens CD19 and CD23, to have circulating CLL cells at a level less than 5 x 10"/L. Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia may occur
  • • ? Hypogammaglobulinemia is common can be associated with significant risk for infections, primarily of mucocutaneous etiology such as sinusitis and bronchitis.
  • • ? One of the most devastating complications of CLL is Richter's transformation, which is transformation of CLL to an aggressive lymphoma, most commonly DLBCL.

A patient receiving chemotherapy develops neutropenia. He presents with fever, cough, expectoration, chest pain and hemoptysis. His CT scan of chest reveals nodular infiltrates with halo sign and crescent sign. The most useful drug for treating him is
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Risk factors are:- Neutropenia:, solid organ or allogeneic stem cell transplantation, prolonged high-dose glucocorticoid therapy, leukaemia and other haematological malignancies, cytotoxic chemotherapy, advanced HIV disease, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, critically ill patients on intensive care units, chronic granulomatous disease.
  • • Culture or histopathological evidence of Aspergillus in diseased tissues provides a definitive diagnosis
  • • Treatment: The drug of choice is voriconazole. Second-line drugs are liposomal amphotericin, caspofungin, posaconazole and isavuconazole. Response may be assessed by estimation of the circulating galactomannan level. Posaconazole (200 mg 3 times daily) or itraconazole (200 mg/day) may be prescribed for primary prophylaxis

questions.text: Which one of the following is an indication for self-injectable adrenaline (epinephrine)?

questions.text: Which of the following statements with regard to arterio-venous fistula in dialysis patient are correct? 1. Distension and thickening of vessel wall occurs 2. Formed upto a year before dialysis is contemplated 3. Leg veins are usually preferred 4. Synthetic graft may be used if fistula formation is not possible Select the correct answer using the code given below:
An infant was born at 30 weeks of gestation and weighs 1-2 kg at birth. Which of the following is the recommended initial feeding method?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Term neonates lose 1-3% birth wt/d with cumulative loss 5-10% in the first week. Preterm neonates lose 2-3% birth wt/d with cumulative loss 10-15% in first week. Failure of wt loss in first week is indicative of excessive fluid administration. Excessive (>3%) loss/day in 5-7 days is non physiological.
  • • Robust sucking pattern is not present until 32- 34 weeks gestation. Coordination between sucking, swallowing and breathing does not mature till 34 weeks and fully matures by 37 to 38 weeks of gestation. Expressed breast milk should start within hour so that infant gets colostrum. Expressed milk can be stored for about 6 hours at room temperature and for 24 hours in domestic refrigerator (2° to 8°C). Enteral feeding is important for sick neonates. Sepsis is not contraindication of enteral feeding unless associated with shock, sclerema, NEC.
  • • Infants who are fed by spoon/paladai or by intragastric tube:- VLBW infants (<1500 g) need about 80 mL/kg fluids on the first day of life can be increased by 10-15 mL/kg/day to a maximum 160 mL/kg/ day by the end of the first week. LBW infants (>1500 g) are given 60 mL/kg fluids on the first day and increased by about 15-20 mL/kg/ day to a maximum of 160 ml/kg/ day by the end of the first week. Birth weight of 1500-2499 g (34 weeks) need additional vitamin D and iron supplement.
  • • A well-hydrated baby should pass urine at 1 to 3 ml/kg/hr. Growth monitoring of LBW infant:-Both term and preterm LBW infants lose weight (about 10% and 15%, respectively) in the first 7 days of life; they regain their birth weight by 10-14 days. After that wt gain should be at least 15-20 g/kg/day till a weight reach upto 2-2.5 kg. After that weight gain of 20 to 40 g/ day is considered appropriate.

questions.text: A newborn delivered at 32 weeks gestation is started on spoon feeds after birth. On feeding with spoon, the baby demonstrates some spilling and coughing. What is the next step in management?

Antidote to reverse the muscarinic effects of organophosphate toxicity is

A 7 year old child is brought to the emergency with seizures and drowsiness. The child had been receiving some drugs for fever for the past two days. Child is found to be cyanosed with an oxygen saturation of 40% and unresponsive to oxygen therapy. Blood gas analysis reveals a normal PaO2. Which drug intake may have caused the above condition?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Chloroquine is well absorbed orally has a large volume of distribution; accumulates especially in heart, kidney, liver, pancreas, lung and spleen, and is strongly bound in melanin-containing cells (eye and skin). Renal excretion enhanced by acidification of the urine. C/F :- Malaise, anorexia, pruritus, urticaria, haemolytic anaemia, methaemoglobinaemia, retinopathy, psychosis, seizures, convulsions, vertigo, headache. Sudden apnoea can occur. CVS manifestations comprise hypotension, atrioventricular conduction defects, and cardiac arrhythmias. Hypokalemia is often present. Effects of chloroquine retinopathy rare pigmentary stippling, mottling, a "bull's eye" pattern of macular hyperpigmentation, attenuation of the retinal arteries, pale optic discs, disturbance of colour vision, loss of central vision scotoma and visual field defects. Features of methemoglobinemia may be asymptomatic or lethargy, stupor, seizure. Acute methemoglobinemia is life threatening when MetHb >50% of total circulatory haemoglobin. ABG reveals normal PaO, and low SpO, Filter paper test shows blood is chocolate coloured not changing after exposure to oxygen. Treatment is methylene blue. Patients with G6PD deficiency should not receive methylene blue. Other t/t are ascorbic acid, hyperbaric oxygen and exchange transfusion. Indications of severe toxicity: (i) systolic BP < 90 mmHg, (ii) QRS duration>110 ms, (ii) hypokalaemia (K+<3.0 mEq). Cardiovascular effects include hypotension, vasodilation, ECG abnormalities (prolonged PR, QRS, and QT interval), ventricular arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse. Fatal dose: As little as 2.25 to 3 grams in an adult. About 2 to 3 times the therapeutic dose may be fatal in children.
  • • Chloroquine is well absorbed orally has a large volume of distribution; accumulates especially in heart, kidney, liver, pancreas, lung and spleen, and is strongly bound in melanin-containing cells (eye and skin). Renal excretion enhanced by acidification of the urine.
  • • C/F :- Malaise, anorexia, pruritus, urticaria, haemolytic anaemia, methaemoglobinaemia, retinopathy, psychosis, seizures, convulsions, vertigo, headache. Sudden apnoea can occur. CVS manifestations comprise hypotension, atrioventricular conduction defects, and cardiac arrhythmias. Hypokalemia is often present. Effects of chloroquine retinopathy rare pigmentary stippling, mottling, a "bull's eye" pattern of macular hyperpigmentation, attenuation of the retinal arteries, pale optic discs, disturbance of colour vision, loss of central vision scotoma and visual field defects.
  • • Features of methemoglobinemia may be asymptomatic or lethargy, stupor, seizure. Acute methemoglobinemia is life threatening when MetHb >50% of total circulatory haemoglobin. ABG reveals normal PaO, and low SpO, Filter paper test shows blood is chocolate coloured not changing after exposure to oxygen. Treatment is methylene blue. Patients with G6PD deficiency should not receive methylene blue. Other t/t are ascorbic acid, hyperbaric oxygen and exchange transfusion.
  • • Indications of severe toxicity: (i) systolic BP < 90 mmHg, (ii) QRS duration>110 ms, (ii) hypokalaemia (K+<3.0 mEq).
  • • Cardiovascular effects include hypotension, vasodilation, ECG abnormalities (prolonged PR, QRS, and QT interval), ventricular arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse.
  • • Fatal dose: As little as 2.25 to 3 grams in an adult. About 2 to 3 times the therapeutic dose may be fatal in children.

questions.text: Autism Spectrum Disorder is characterized by which of the following" 1. Onset before 3 years of age 2. Impaired verbal and gestural communication 3. Stereotypic and restrictive behavioural patterns 4. Tangential speech Select the correct answer using the code given below:
Which vaccines are stored in the top rack of the main refrigerator compartment at temperature of 4-10°C?

options.label: A
options.text: DPT, Hepatitis B, Measles, MMR vaccines

questions.correct_answer: D. BCG, Measles and MMR vaccines
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Measles, BCG, rota virus vaccine and OPV on the top shelf. DPT, pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, hepatitis B, and JE vaccine on the middle shelf and diluents next to vaccine with which they are supplied Ice-packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the door of the refrigerator. Vaccine placed in the ice lined refrigerator (ILR):- All the vaccines should be kept in the basket provided with the ILR. ILR cabinet temperature is between +2°C to + 8°C and are used to store vaccines at district and sub-district level. It is top opening refrigerators. In case basket is not available, two layers of empty ice-packs can be laid flat on the bottom of the ILR. DPT, TT, hep B, IPV and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in upper part of the basket. Upper part is preferred location for storing the freeze sensitive vaccines Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE (in the sub-district stores, OPV is kept in ILR, unlike higher level vaccine stores, where it is kept in DF) can be kept at bottom of the basket (coldest part) Vaccines should never be kept directly on the floor of the refrigerator as they can freeze and get damaged while ampoule of BCG vaccine can crack.
  • • Measles, BCG, rota virus vaccine and OPV on the top shelf.
  • • DPT, pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, hepatitis B, and JE vaccine on the middle shelf and diluents next to vaccine with which they are supplied
  • • Ice-packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the door of the refrigerator.
  • • Vaccine placed in the ice lined refrigerator (ILR):- All the vaccines should be kept in the basket provided with the ILR. ILR cabinet temperature is between +2°C to + 8°C and are used to store vaccines at district and sub-district level. It is top opening refrigerators. In case basket is not available, two layers of empty ice-packs can be laid flat on the bottom of the ILR.
  • • DPT, TT, hep B, IPV and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in upper part of the basket. Upper part is preferred location for storing the freeze sensitive vaccines
  • • Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE (in the sub-district stores, OPV is kept in ILR, unlike higher level vaccine stores, where it is kept in DF) can be kept at bottom of the basket (coldest part)
  • • Vaccines should never be kept directly on the floor of the refrigerator as they can freeze and get damaged while ampoule of BCG vaccine can crack.
  • • Order in which vaccine loses its potency when exposed to heat:- Group A→ Most sensitive & Group F→ least sensitive
  • • Vaccines sensitive to light:- BCG, measles, measles-rubella, measles-mumps-rubella and rubella. These vaccines are supplied in dark glass vials.

questions.text: Identification of '4Ds' is a key element of which National Health Programme?

options.label: A
options.text: IMNCI (Integrated Management of Childhood and Neonatal illness)
